title: Does AOC ever have a shot at becoming President? - Quora
tags: Presidents of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Obviously, not for a while at least. She is way too young and does not meet the age requirement. Down the road is a different thing. She has an aggressive personality (and I do not meant that in a negative way)and is outspoken and has made a pretty big splash for a freshman congresswoman. She is articulate and seems quite knowledgeable. She does, however, need some ‘seasoning’ , must gain experience. All this being said she certainly has the capacity as well as the potential to become president. A problem that she is going to face, indeed, is facing right now, is the fact that the Republicans (though they won’t admit it) have already identified her as a potential problem, a potential adversary for the office of president, down the road and their mainstay procedure of dirty tricks is already being employed relative to her. They take the slightest thing, such as the video of her dancing, or her boyfriend gaining email access to her (and not being given a job by her) to make fun and ridicule her. They have already started to do to her what they did to Hillary Clinton (and it worked) by damaging her image so much that they keep her from being elected. There was a time a long time ago, when the Republican Party was an honest and decent political entity. In many cases the Democrats were, years ago, more reprehensible than were the Republicans. BUT, those times have changed, drastically which is why I left the Republican party many.many years ago. The downfall began with, probably, Richard Nixon and went into overdrive with Reagan and his lackey, Newt Gingrich when they courted the religious right. It now is the haven for most of the true bigots, racists as well as the height of hypocrisy the fundamentalist evangelicals. In my book they are the worst of the lot, all those FAKE CHRISTIANS who profess one thing but live and accept the complete opposite as represented by Trump and their adulation of him. The Republicans nowadays resort to any kind of heinous activity to retain power and influence. They depend on gerrymandering and voter suppression and engage in all the ‘dirty tricks’ they can think of to sway the voters. The Swift Boating video is a typical example. The reason I brought all this out is because their dirty tricks actions is so well developed and consistent that they are automatically attempting to degrade the image of AOC. This is, to me, one thing that could prevent her from becoming president, depending on the degree of success they meet in this endeavor. Otherwise I would say yes, her chance of becoming president sometime down the road is pretty darned good.

A decent chance. In 2019, AOC, a 29-year-old freshman representative, is the cat’s meow to progressives. In 2024, the media cycle will have long moved on, so the jury will be out on whether she is still relevant. Tradition says probably. Bernie Sanders is still popular after 2016, Trump was still popular after 2012, and so AOC can still be popular after 2020 (though she’s not running for president, she practically has the media coverage of a candidate). So, if she’s still relevant, she’ll be turning 35 shortly before Election Day 2024. And remember, that’s the earliest possible time she could run. Maybe she’ll stay in New York, run for Senate or Governor, maybe stay in the House and try to be Speaker or Majority/Minority Leader. She certainly has a lot of elections ahead of her, but I think it would be best for her to run sooner rather than later. Her whole appeal is her freshness and newness. In, say, 2052, she won’t be new anymore. She’ll be another politician in the crowd. As for her actual chances at securing her nomination and the election, I think it’s definitely conceivable. Her nomination chances would be dependent mostly on college students, millennials, and non-millennial leftists. Certainly possible - Sanders won a lot of state through this process in 2016, and by 2024 these population sizes will have grown to more of the electorate. So, saying she secures her party’s nomination, the general election is where things get more complicated. 2024 will see a new Republican nominee, but if Trump is re-elected in 2020 then America may be sick of Republican leadership by that point (since Truman followed FDR, there have only ever been three terms of the same party one other time - Reagan and Bush). So, in that case, tradition would be on AOC’s side. But AOC is the kind of person that throws tradition to the wind. Would the Republican candidate pose as a moderate to counteract AOC’s avowed democratic socialism? I’m not sure how that would turn out. I think it’s possible AOC could become president, but I’m not sure what her future holds.

Well, just at the moment, she’s not qualified for the office and can not run. She won’t be old enough until the 2024 cycle; and even then she won’t be powerful and experienced enough. That said, I don’t really like her chances. Never mind her politics— she’s too far left right now, but she’s also barely out of diapers and this can change— but because of her positioning. For one thing, she’s not a lawyer. That’s not a complete proscription, but the most common route to the presidency is through a governor’s mansion, and the most common route to the governor’s mansion is through the State Attorney General’s office. So, while not a bar, it is a handicap. Another problem is she’s New York. NY is our third most populous state. That makes it easier to get elected to Congress— there are a lot of seats— but harder to move up in rank because NY only has two Senators and one governor, and there’s a lot of competition for those slots. Moreover, she’s a left-wing princess and a POC. This makes her a good fit for her district, but not as attractive as a state-wide candidate. Her biggest issue right now is having a district to run in for 2022. NY is almost certainly going to lose a seat in the House following this year’s census. They might lose two of them. Her seat is going to be high on the list to vanish. She has been abrasive and annoying to her superiors both in the House— I cannot believe she thought it was a good idea to stage a sit-in in Nancy Pelosi’s office; Her Nancyship is not known to forgive such slights— and in her home state. The legislature will have a very hard time getting rid of another Republican; they’ve already got them gerrymandered into about as few seats as can be legally managed. If you’ll look at her district, you will see it is surrounded by a lot of long-term and powerful members of the House. But never say never in politics. She’s hella smart, just woefully uneducated and has a severe reality deficit. She can outgrow those, if she survives the ’22 election. She’s been keeping a low profile lately, and this is wise of her. More to the point, she’s a big electoral speaking draw and raises money a lot faster than most freshmen. If she can keep that up for 10 or 15 years, she can wangle a good committee chair, or a leadership slot. From there a cabinet position is not impossible, and she might parlay that into the governor’s mansion. It is not impossible. But it is less likely. She is not well positioned.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Lara Landis and Lucy Vaughn

response.answer_text: ANSWERED 13 MARCH 2019 - UPDATED 26 MAY 2019— A very thoughtful answer was written by Dr. Judy Klass. She reminds us that among other things, ACO must wait until she’s 35 years old to even become eligible. By my calculation, that would mean the 2024 election. Here’s the problem. If a Democrat wins in 2020, that person would typically run for two terms. Now, given the fickleness of voters, it’s not likely they would vote for another Democrat in 2028 (I recall a neighbor saying she was going to vote for Ike in 1952 just because she thought the country needed a change). I was in the 5th grade. I remember my mom quizzing our neighbor about her decision. “Are you upset with the Democrats,” she wanted to know. “No,” said our neighbor. “It’s just time for a change.” Our neighbor admitted that she loved Harry Truman, and FDR before him. She thought that Adlai Stevenson would carry on their tradition, should he win in 1952. She didn’t particularly like Ike, and really didn’t like Republicans. Still, she told my mom that the country had had too much of the Democrats. My mom kept quizzing her, but she never really got a substantive answer. So, our neighbor voted for Ike. Year’s later, in 2000, I heard the same comment from one of my neighbors. This neighbor was a Democrat and couldn’t bring herself to vote for “W.” Still, she thought the country needed a change after the Clinton years, so she was voted for Ralph Nader, throwing the election into a tie. We all know how that turned out. I will never forgive my neighbor, or Ralph Nader for his arrogance. But back to AOC and her problem. It might be that she couldn’t run until 2036. If my math is correct, she’ll be 47 years old. Still young, and still vibrant. I can think of a lot of if’s in front of AOC between now and 2036. Dr. Klass has mentioned many of them. I won’t do a repeat here. I’ll close by saying let’s pray that today’s House Dems will stop this President from destroying our Democratic/Republic so that AOC still has a Presidency she can run for. Since your asked, I believe the House Dems will stop him. Semper Fi, JE-PhD—Political Science (Political Theory, Economics, History, Mathematics) “Old Corps, New Corps, Same Corps”

It’s much too early to tell. She’s a brand new member of Congress. She showed good, tactical instincts in her political campaign against a seasoned incumbent — a fellow Democrat who did not see her upset primary victory coming. She’s articulate, and respected economists like Paul Krugman have good things to say about some of her ideas, and she knows how to make effective use of social media. She made excellent, efficient use of her time questioning Michael Cohen — she really handled that well. It’s also impressive how she has virtually the entire right-wing chattering class obsessing about her, raging against her, foaming at the mouth over her, distorting her views, stalking her and so on … Still, I’m a little troubled by her line in an interview suggesting that the main thing is to be morally right, instead of “precisely, factually and semantically correct.” It’s possible to over-emphasize that comment of hers. But I think that the greatest distinction between Democrats and Republicans these days is that Democrats believe in the fact-based universe, and in science, and in fact-checked journalism, and Democrats believe the intelligence that the people who work for our country risk their lives to gather, and believe in being rigorous and careful when presenting ideas and statistics and in making the case for a policy proposal. Republicans are more like Trump these days, which is a disaster and a tragedy for the nation; they have left the fact-based universe far behind. If honest journalists get something wrong, they admit it and print a retraction — and people in politics, and people on Quora (it happens to all of us at some point) should simply do the same. And obviously, there are tests of leadership ahead for AOC. Can she put together a piece of legislation that others will want to vote for? Can she build coalitions with people who think differently (other Democrats and perhaps even Republicans) and get things done? Can she advocate for the kinds of change she wants while remaining respectful of those who disagree? There are many kinds of situations that will come up for a stateswoman who is this early in her career, and since it will be years before she is eligible to run for President, she has time to show what she’s made of in lots of ways.

Hey Clinton! I can answer that question… In the past year, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has skyrocketed to political fame in America as a progressive firebrand who advocates on behalf of workers, the environment, people of colour, and for universal healthcare. With more than two dozen Democrats running for president, many of them unknown to the vast majority of the United States, the question has popped up -- why isn't she on the debate stage in Miami? Well, there are a couple reasons why the New York Democrat may not be throwing her hat into the overcrowded ring: She says she doesn't want it, literally just got into Congress, and her age happens to be an issue. The first two reasons aside, AOC's youth is the biggest obstacle to her taking on Donald Trump in 2020. That's because the US Constitution sets the minimum age requirement at 35-years-old. Ms Ocasio-Cortez, at the present moment, is only 29-years-old. It brings her the distinction of being the youngest woman to ever serve in Congress. But, she has to wait six years if she hopes to make a run for the Oval Office. Donald Trump's shocking victory in the 2016 presidential race caused liberals across the United States to question whether the country was indeed ready for a woman president. Since then, there has been much speculation about various female politicians and celebrities running for office, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, Senator Kamala Harris, Oprah, Michelle Obama, and others. There have even been rumours that Hillary Clinton might run again. I, however, don't see any of these women making it to the White House. I think the first female president of the US will AOC. It may take her another six years to get there, but the youngest woman elected to the US Congress will win the presidency. Here is how and why. Hillary Clinton won the popular vote in the 2016 election but lost key swing states and, under our complicated and arguably unfair Electoral College system, this meant losing the presidency. But the biggest political upset in recent US history cannot simply be blamed on the unfairness of the electoral system, under which countless Democrats managed to defeat opponents stronger, and more experienced, than Donald Trump. Clinton lost the election because she failed to convince working-class voters that she would be able to understand and address their growing grievances. While she started her journey as a young, educated, idealistic feminist believing in social justice and equality, over the course of her life in the political limelight, she (and her husband) madea fortune of over $50m, including $21m in speaking fees she was paid by Wall Street businesses and other interest groups. She gradually became an unrelatable poster-child of corporate America's greed. This, combined with the proliferation of fake news and misinformation provided by Trump's campaign were the proverbial "nails in the coffin" for her presidential bid. Unlike Clinton and most politicians for that matter, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez rejected donations from corporate political action committees, or PACs. She didn't take millions from Wall Street and then preach to blue-collar Americans that she understood their struggles. This helped her not to be perceived as a member of the Washington establishment like Clinton and her peers Senators Elizabeth Warren and Kirsten Gillibrand, for example. Moreover, Clinton just offered middle-of-the-road policies that simply promised more of the same. By contrast, Ocasio-Cortez, as an out and proud democratic socialist, advocated for federally guaranteed jobs and "Medicare-For-All," called for tuition-free public colleges and the dismantling of the US Immigration and Customs Enforcement. With this, AOC made it clear that she offers a different kind of politics that is unadulterated by corporate and lobbyist connections. This is, in fact, what helped her defeat a 20-year incumbent and the fourth-ranking House Democrat, Joe Crowley, in the Democratic race for New York's 14th Congressional District. After she was sworn into Congress, she continued talking about progressive policies, calling for a return to John F Kennedy's 70 percent tax on the wealthiest Americans and supporting a "Green New Deal", a proposed economic programme addressing climate change and inequality. If Ocasio-Cortez continues down this path and successfully rejects cooptation by PACs, working-class Americans across party lines would undoubtedly be moved to vote for her. AOC is also a master of grassroots organising and, while her actions convey that she is in touch with the challenges ordinary Americans face, her greatest asset may be her ability to connect with them in a way that feels genuine and not contrived. Millennials, for example, find AOC more relatable than any other potential presidential candidate. With her 2.37 million Twitter followers and growing, she is a skilled social media user who knows how to connect and communicate with the younger generation and will certainly be able to secure their vote. And in the coming decade, it increasingly seems that it will be the millennials who will become the most important voting bloc within the US electorate. And finally, AOC was also able to capture the attention of the press and has already shown much skill in fending off public attacks. Even before she was sworn into office on January 3, conservatives had already launched a smear campaign against her, which is indicative of how much she scares them. With the election of Trump and AOC's rise to stardom, one thing has become undoubtedly clear: US voters are desperate for new politics and fresh faces who can offer real change. And with her charisma, presence and political acumen, Ocasio-Cortez is able to tap into these sentiments. To put it in Trump's words, Ocasio-Cortez is a "winner", she is "winning". Her popularity in the press parallels Trump's during his presidential bid in 2016 when he proved true the cliché "any press is good press". Yes, it was thanks to the media's obsession with him, both on the right and the left, that he remained a constant figure in the public eye, which ultimately paved the way for the unimaginable to happen - his win over Hillary Clinton in the 2016 presidential election. The same is already proving true for AOC. She is the Democrat that Republicans (and even some Democrats) love to hate, and she will be all the better for it.

No, for many reasons. Firstly she’s far too radical. She has said many bad things against military personnel and police officers. Her quote about stealing a million dollars and how capitalism is irredeemable. She’s arguably more far left than Bernie and he didn’t win the nomination twice so if he can’t AOC certainly can’t. I’m one of the view Democrats who dislikes AOC very much, I think she often talks down to her base and says whatever her dumb supporters want to hear. She also puts feelings above facts in many situations and that gives the whole party a bad name. If she was ever the Democratic nominee, I along with many moderates would hold our noses and vote for the republican.

Very good I'd say. She's very popular among young people who also tend to lean more progressive and support the same policy positions she does. She's still very young so by the time she runs for office, the demographics of the US will have changed. More states will be blue, including Texas. More baby boomers will have passed on. The younger, more progressive demographics will have a larger proportion of the vote. AOC will have more experience. She'll be better at campaigning, at rhetoric. She'll be smarter, wiser. The impetus for change, greater. Barring some unforeseen meteoric change in circumstances, it would really not surprise me if she becomes president in the future.

Until she is old enough to run, it doesn’t matter if she has the right stuff or not. However, from what can be observed of her right this moment, for her to have “the right stuff” when she is 35, she will have to acquire a complete replacement of the “stuff” she has now. This is largely because the “stuff” she has now consists of a set of handlers who feed her every thought she has, and work overtime trying to prevent her from exhibiting how little “stuff” she has on her own, to maintain the illusion that she isn’t a complete waste of oxygen.

It really depends on who she is against. I mean she has no chance of winning if people realize that her policies are not going to work and it’s so unrealistic (The Green New Deal and putting a 70% marginal tax rate on people making over 10 million dollars) If she gets her stuff together and notice that her ideas are stupid and won’t work and she can actually make some realistic and good policies then she has a great chance of winning because she has the voice and has the audience but right now she is just ruining her career by making the dumbest policies.

Yes, I do. She is one politically savvy young woman. Thanks to Sanders getting young people politically excited, I have little doubt the party is slowly but surely moving leftward. The older, more conservative Baby Boomers are losing their voting block due to health conditions and just age. People die. The younger generation, unhappy with the conservative status quo, is beginning to see the power of their votes. They are liberal, and they want to push the Democratic Party into being a liberal party again instead of its current conservative state. That said, in 20 to 30 years, AOC will gain more experience and more support. I definitely see a presidential run in her future, and quite possibly, a presidential win.

It really depends if we allow hateful rhetoric and racists like white nationalist and donald chump continue to go unpunished. If the voters show that hateful people like donald chump is not acceptable and vote him out. Then, the next president could focus on the domestic terrorists known as white nationalist and help pass laws that focus on domestic terrorism, then that will show that our country has progressed which will be perfect for an AOC bid for the white house. It's all about progress vs the good ol boy system.

President of what? The Justin Bieber Fan Club? Sure. President if the United States, not in your wildest dreams. I give her credit, She saw an opportunity and seized the day. Can’t fault her for that. She is not afraid to say what she really thinks without hesitation, good for her. Unfortunately for her, when it comes to real world issues she is dumber than a bag of rocks. She allows ideology to win out over common sense and as a result her district lost thousands of high paying jobs. And liberals complain about Trump!

Do you think AOC’s got the right stuff to be President? No, when caught Lying, she defends her Lies. “There's a lot of people more concerned about being precisely, factually, and semantically correct than about being morally right,” @AOC says in response to criticism that she’s made factual errors. More AOC: Facts don't matter when you're "morally right" 1st Lying is Lying 2nd She wasn’t Morally Right to defend her Lies.

Not in the near future. She’s too green. She has only been doing this for a year and a half. Let her get some experience under her belt, learn to horse trade, learn the definition of a good deal is one where everybody involved thinks they got screwed a little bit, but everybody also got something they wanted. (A lot of the people in both houses of Congress need to learn this.) Then she will be formidable.

She’s too young to legally qualify, but she will be old enough in 2024. Although her constituents really like her, she hasn’t yet shown an ability to win suburban and rural areas. If she is elected governor of New York or as a U.S. senator from New York, she will have proven an ability to win a statewide contest. After a few years in that office, she’d have the resume to be taken seriously as a presidential candidate.

President of what? Surely you don’t mean the United States???? That would be almost as ridiculous as suggesting that someone like … Joe Biden or Al Gore would be a good candidate. Unless you’re a comedy writer, they’re not even worth considering.

It is impossible to know at this time but I wouldn’t bet against it. What did the last two Democratic presidents have that Hillary and Al Gore didn’t have. Charisma. AOC ‘s got it in spades. Why do you think she is the most covered new congress person in history. She has more followers than anyone else in congress. Unless she really screws up she will have a great chance if she wants it.

0%. Convincing one congressional district that a person with the IQ of a sheet of paper is fit for elected office is much easier than convincing 51% of the whole nation. Besides according to her the earth is going to cease to exist in less than twelve years so there will be nothing for her to be president of.

Are you f—- kidding. One moron wasn’t enough for you. Hey let the lefties take a shot of putting a total idiot in the White House, the righties did it. No way. This country needs healing. No more racially antagonizing puppets and megalomaniac s like Obama and Trump. Yes that’s right I said Obama too. He’s not innocent.

I think there’s a very solid chance that she will, though maybe not for a while. She’s got the intelligence, the drive, the honesty, and the power of inherent authenticity.  I’m not sure what the U.S. would be like with a president like that again - but I wouldn’t mind finding out.

Not this time around she is too young. By the time she is old enough to run the Dem establishment will have managed to push her out. They are currently running scared of her and looking for a way to shut her down. They are paying lip service to her ideas because she has a large social media following but knows that her ideas are downright crazy.

No, but not for the reasons the Cult will give but because to restore America to TRUE greatness you need a Government that doesn’t choose sides, but represents ALL the people, not just their base. AOC is not that candidate.

The US just elected a game show host who likes to surround himself with future felons, white nationalists, etc., and who has admitted to keeping a copy of “Mein Kampf” by his bedside in the past. And that just scratches the surface. In America, anything is possible. What a country!
Hard to guess. She does well fighting Trump. She speaks for folk who want no nonsense change. She knows the naysayers in Congress have to be defeated. She means it.
I think it’s extremely unlikely. She would have to learn to appeal to a lot of people who currently view her as something like the daughter of Satan.
She’s not all that popular in her own district. She will become yesterday’s news after she’s primaried by someone with a brain.
AOC could not win dog catcher in a one person race. She is extreme, self aggrandizing, runs her mouth w/o facts, ran Amazon out of NY and cost NY millions, jobs, etc. A loose cannon loser.
Would be the worst thing that could happen to this country. A few years ago clowns like her would be laughed off the stage. Thanks to the liberal media they are now in the fore front
Right now it appears that AOC might have difficulty remaining in Congress, considering how her constituents are complaining that she has made little effort to represent them.

She could in like 5 years or so? I dont exactly know her age but Im pretty sure the age requirement to be POTUS is 35. Besides, from what Ive seen shes not interested in running either. I would definetly encourage a young person like that if she ever decides to however. I love seeing her on cspan. Shes passionate about her viewpoints and she does her homework. I respect that

No, she’s to far left. No very far right or very far left person will ever be elected to be president. The people who actually pick the winner, are those that that waver left and right. Sometimes voting one way and sometimes voting another. These people are centrist. To far from center and a centrist will not vote for you.
Let’s ALL hope NOT !
Since Congress unanimously rejected her crazy environmental plan, and Congress can't agree on the color of grass, that would be a hearty NO.
Not anytime too soon. Maybe let’s see how she does in congress before promoting her to president.
Certainly none in the near future, and if I had to bet on ever I would say unlikely. But never say never.
Well, she’s the brightest progressive in congress, so I think she has a good shot.
Now? None. Too young for it anyway. 10-20 years from now? Maybe….
